THANK YOU @nwlc @HRC for your dedicated work to share info and insight on the gender pay gap -- it collectively empowers us to push for better for all!

Not only does it take working several more years to "catch up", the gender pay gap means women have less retirement security for the same work. 

This endangers women, their families + puts older women at risk of homelessness.

LGBTQ+ working women face a 13% gender pay gap which compounds for Black and Brown LGBTQ+ women. 

Trans women only make $0.60 for every $1 paid to men.

Black women make $0.67 for every $1 paid to men. 

That means:
$1,891 in wages lost every month
$22,692 lost every year
$907,000 lost over 40 years

Latinas make $0.57 for every $1 paid to men. 

That means:
$2,477 in wages lost every month
$29,724 lost every year 
$1.19 million lost over 40 years

The gender pay gap is a policy choice that robs women hundreds of thousands of dollars over a lifetime. We need more women + allies in elected office and decision-making roles to rectify this NOW.

Economic justice isn‚Äôt just about whether the people who do get relief deserve it. It‚Äôs about who is being ignored.
In the richest country in the world, we can afford to help working people facing economic hardships in their lives with the same urgency as we rush to aid the victims of bank runs.

I also believe that the people of East Palestine and Jackson, Mississippi deserve the same sense of urgency as depositors at SVB. Elected officials and the media need to step up not only in delivering tangible relief, but also recognizing human suffering that isn‚Äôt on the coasts.

And @ewarren is right that we must reform deposit insurance to ensure that in times of crisis businesses can still make payroll. The money for this should come from the banks that are taking the risk and reaping the benefits in good times.

.@LeverNews has reported on the successful efforts of bank lobbyists to avoid paying more into the Deposit Insurance Fund. This is shameful. Banks must pay higher premiums to fund depositors‚Äô insurance. This will incentivize more responsible management and less risky behavior.

SVB chief executive Greg Becker sold $3.6 million worth of shares on February 27th. I have said that there should be a clawback of that money. Whatever his motives, and we should find out, that $3.6 million should go to depositors.

Shareholders and executives at banks like SVB should not benefit from either taxpayer dollars or the help of the FDIC to secure buyers without being compelled to submit to regulations that amount to more than a slap on the wrist.
Medium-sized banks like SVB managed to avoid stress tests/liquidity and capital requirements that could have prevented this predictable disaster.

The run on SVB is a reminder of the need to impose strong financial regulations on banks. The Republican Party succeeded in passing the bill eviscerating Dodd-Frank against the warnings of progressives like myself and @BernieSanders.

A thread on some of my takeaways from the SVB collapse. SVB is in my district, but I did not hesitate to tell them no when they lobbied hard for Donald Trump's bill to weaken Dodd-Frank. I voted against the bill. Too many Dems voted yes.
